org.hl7.xml.parser
Class TreeContentHandler

java.lang.Object
  org.hl7.xml.parser.DynamicContentHandlerBase
      org.hl7.xml.parser.TreeContentHandler
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Cloneable, DynamicContentHandler, org.xml.sax.ContentHandler
Direct Known Subclasses:
ADPresenter.ADContentHandler, ADXPPresenter.ADXPContentHandler, CDPresenter.CDContentHandler, CEPresenter.CEContentHandler, CRPresenter.CRContentHandler, CVPresenter.CVContentHandler, EDPresenter.EDContentHandler, ENXPPresenter.ENXPContentHandler, ONPresenter.ONContentHandler, ONXPPresenter.ONXPContentHandler, PNPresenter.PNContentHandler, PNXPPresenter.PNXPContentHandler, PQRPresenter.PQRContentHandler, QSETPresenter.QSETContentHandler
public class TreeContentHandler
extends DynamicContentHandlerBase
implements DynamicContentHandler, java.lang.Cloneable

A DynamicContentHandler used to generate small (mini-DOM) trees that can be used in two ways: - as an intermediary representation for a value constructor to get the parameters. - as a default representation for yet unhandled types or unknown field extensions. Since I love Saxon so much, I am tempted to building a Saxon Tinytree. If I did that I would have access to Saxon's XPath functions as well as would be able to quickly exchange tree fragments with Saxon XSLT transforms. On the other hand, JDOM seems to be the way to go today. But who knows. For now I keep it simple, but could change that.

Version:

Author:
Gunther Schadow, Regenstrief Institute

Field Detail

attributes_

protected final org.xml.sax.helpers.AttributesImpl attributes_
Use this object to avoid creating a new instance of AttributesImpl on each startElement(). Make sure you call attributes.clear() immediately after startElement().

Constructor Detail

TreeContentHandler

public TreeContentHandler(java.lang.String namespaceURI,
                          java.lang.String localName,
                          java.lang.String qName,
                          org.xml.sax.Attributes atts)
A TreeContentHandler must be given the name of the root node, since nothing else would allow us to reconstruct the name. Rememeber, this could be an extension element (Z-element in HL7-speak.)
